I was personally enriched by her life! My deepest sympathy to her children and her many wonderful grandchildren. May she rest in peace and rest mightily in power.

She fought for parks, more housing, and she was a very strong advocate for Houston‚Äôs children. Let us resoundingly thank her for her life and legacy and give her the best tribute, which is to continue to help the most vulnerable wherever they are.

She was able to communicate that history to all Houstonians. Councilmember Edwards always believed that we could attain a just world where everyone was treated with dignity. As I stated earlier, she was loved by many, and it was a joy to see her in and out of her community.

She was a friend and supporter of one of our great institutions, the Shape Community Center and she was one of the best at articulating the unique African ancestry of our African American neighborhoods.

You never had to worry about seeing Councilmember Edwards in the neighborhoods as an elected official or simply as a community activist and leader. You could always count on her bright smile and you knew she had a desire to help whoever it was that was in need.
As a Houston Councilmember, she enjoyed being a problem solver and took on problems with a fierceness and a belief that it would be resolved in favor of the many vulnerable people she represented.

We are all deeply saddened by the passing of a beloved community leader, our own former Councilmember Ada Edwards. Ada loved her constituents and her constituents loved her. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fr9la_UWwAIhdvu.jpg

Finally, the U.S. Senate this week sent a terrible signal when it comes to Iran and the fight against radical Islam.

President Obama and Vice President Biden made the mistake of pulling all American troops out of Iraq.  It led to the rise of ISIS, establishment of a Caliphate in Raqqa and spawned attacks by radical jihadists in both Europe and the United States.  We must not repeat that mistake

America has only one path available when attacked ‚Äì respond swiftly and vigorously with overwhelming, punishing force designed to make enemies wary of engaging with the United States.

This bill spells out it clearly: the 1st Amendment guarantees parents the right to assemble and express their opinions on decisions affecting their children and communities.

Claim: This legislation creates onerous ‚Äúcompliance requirements.‚Äù
¬†
Reality: Administrators, educators, and parents should be on the same page. It should not be complex to ask for the bare minimum engagement between parents and schools.

Claim: This bill targets teachers.
¬†
Reality: Many teachers are already involving parents in their child‚Äôs education. For these teachers, nothing changes. All this legislation does is ensure we have baseline parental involvement in EVERY school.

Claim: Republicans want to ban books.
¬†
Reality: This bill does nothing to restrict curriculum decisions, which largely exist at the state and local level. It simply makes sure that school districts are transparent about reading materials used in the classroom.
